unnormalised: Paying bills in India, especially for utilities, can feel like navigating a maze sometimes, right? You've got your electricity, water, gas, internet – each with its own due date, payment portal, and let’s not forget, confusing abbreviations. It's a monthly ritual that most of us dread, even with all the online payment options available now. Back in the day, standing in queues at the electricity board office was the norm. My grandpa still remembers those days and grumbles whenever he has to pay the phone bill online. He insists on paying his electricity bill in cash, a habit from his olden days.

unnormalised: Take my electricity bill, for example. It always has some crazy reading like "347.89 kWh" consumed, and then some cryptic charges like "FCA @ Rs. 0.50/unit". What's FCA? And why is it always fluctuating? Plus, there's the "Meter Rent" which seems ridiculously low at just Rs. 15, but still, what's that about? I always end up spending 20 mins just trying to understand it.
normalised: Take my electricity bill, for example. It always has some crazy reading like three hundred and forty seven point eight nine kilowatt hour consumed, and then some cryptic charges like F-C-A at rupee zero point five zero per unit. What's F-C-A? And why is it always fluctuating? Plus, there's the Meter Rent which seems ridiculously low at just rupee fifteen, but still, what's that about? I always end up spending twenty minutes just trying to understand it.

unnormalised: Then there's the water bill. Here in Bangalore, the BWSSB (Bangalore Water Supply and Sewerage Board) sends a bill every month. It's usually around Rs. 500-700, depending on the usage, but there are also those times when the bill shoots up inexplicably. I remember one month, the bill was a whopping Rs. 2500! Turns out there was a leak in the underground pipe, which took ages to fix. Imagine the amount of water wasted and the unnecessary charge!
normalised: Then there's the water bill. Here in Bangalore, the B-W-S-S-B (Bangalore Water Supply and Sewerage Board) sends a bill every month. It's usually around rupee five hundred to seven hundred, depending on the usage, but there are also those times when the bill shoots up inexplicably. I remember one month, the bill was a whopping rupee two thousand five hundred! Turns out there was a leak in the underground pipe, which took ages to fix. Imagine the amount of water wasted and the unnecessary charge!

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on the internet bill. I use Airtel, and they keep sending promotional messages for faster speeds and bundled offers. My current plan is Rs. 999/month for "unlimited" data (with some hidden clauses, of course). Then there's the GST of 18% added on top of that. Sometimes, there are "convenience fees" if you don't use their preferred payment method. Sheesh!

unnormalised: Nowadays, many folks have shifted to online payment platforms. Apps like Paytm and PhonePe, or even UPI, have made it easier than before. You can save your card details and auto-pay your bills. But even then, you have to be careful and double-check everything. My friend, Rohan, almost paid someone else's electricity bill as his meter number (1234567890) was just one digit off from theirs!

unnormalised: I remember seeing one of my neighbours getting a final notice, basically a warning for immediate disconnection, because their bill was overdue. They had apparently missed paying Rs. 350, which accrued late payment charges of Rs. 50. Talk about stress over a few hundred rupees! They hurried off to pay it.

They had apparently missed paying rupee three hundred and fifty, which accrued late payment charges of rupee fifty. Talk about stress over a few hundred rupees! They hurried off to pay it.

unnormalised: Ultimately, keeping on top of utility bills in India is just one of those unavoidable adulting tasks. Whether it's understanding cryptic electricity unit costs, remembering BWSSB, or battling internet provider offers, it is important to be attentive. Whether you're grandpa paying bills in cash or using auto-pay on a mobile app, it's just part of navigating daily life here. My grandma is happy to let her son deal with all of that; she says paying taxes, GST, and all that is all too modern for her. The younger generation in the family is the one who knows all about current utility fees and prices!
